title: Teruo Iwamoto
text:
is a former <a href="Japan">Japan</a>ese <a href="Association%20football">football</a> player. He played for <a href="Japan%20national%20football%20team">Japan national team</a>.
Club career.
Iwamoto was born in <a href="Yokohama">Yokohama</a> on May 2, 1972. After graduating from high school, he joined <a href="Shonan%20Bellmare">Fujita Industries</a> (later "Bellmare Hiratsuka") in 1991. In 1994, the club won <a href="1994%20Emperor%27s%20Cup">1994 Emperor's Cup</a>. In Asia, the club also won <a href="1995%20Asian%20Cup%20Winners%27%20Cup">1995 Asian Cup Winners' Cup</a>. After that, he could not become regular player due to injuries. In the latter the 1990s, he played for <a href="Kyoto%20Sanga%20FC">Kyoto Purple Sanga</a> (1998), <a href="Kawasaki%20Frontale">Kawasaki Frontale</a> (1999) and <a href="Tokyo%20Verdy">Verdy Kawasaki</a> (2000). In 2001, he moved to <a href="Vegalta%20Sendai">Vegalta Sendai</a>. At the club, he became a regular player and assisted many goals. In 2004, he moved to <a href="Nagoya%20Grampus">Nagoya Grampus Eight</a>. However he got hurt in May and he left the club end of the season. In October 2006, he signed with <a href="Auckland%20City%20FC">Auckland City</a> and played until December. In December, he also played at <a href="2006%20FIFA%20Club%20World%20Cup">2006 Club World Cup</a> in Japan. He retired after 2006 Club World Cup.
National team career.
On May 22, 1994, Iwamoto debuted for <a href="Japan%20national%20football%20team">Japan national team</a> against <a href="Australia%20national%20soccer%20team">Australia</a>. He also played at <a href="Football%20at%20the%201994%20Asian%20Games">1994 Asian Games</a>. At Asian Games, he wore the number 10 shirt for Japan. He played 9 games and scored 2 goals for Japan in 1994.
